text: In 2024, if you are having trouble with the command line at 2:40  In the terminal:  python from flaskblog.models import Post from flaskblog import app, db app.app_context().push() posts = Post.query.all() for post in posts: 	print(post)

author: @markusschramm4627
text: Just a comment for all the ones who are confronted with the problem of SQLAlchemy not finding the User or better said not connecting to site.db in the flaskblog-folder.  I needed to define the absolute path to site.db to make it work. Therefore edit __init__.py: add: import os and replace    app.config['SQLALCHEMY_DATABASE_URI'] = 'sqlite:///site.db'  with db_path = os.path.join(os.path.dirname(__file__), 'site.db') app.config['SQLALCHEMY_DATABASE_URI'] = 'sqlite:///{}'.format(db_path)

author: @maroskukan8387
text: If anyone is looking for an easy way how to add those 25 posts Corey mentioned without spending lot of time clicking around in the app itself. You can use Python interactive shell  from flaskblog import db from flaskblog.models import User, Post posts = [{"title": "My Updated Post", "content": "My first updated post!\r\n\r\nThis is exciting!", "user_id": 1}, {"title": "A Second Post",........] for post in posts:    item = Post(title=post['title'], content=post['content'], user_id=post['user_id'])    db.session.add(item)    db.session.commit()    print("Added " + str(post['title']))  Afterwards your site.db file will be populated from values from the list of posts.

author: @user-re6bd3zz5o
text: If you have problem of how you can pass the data from the json file here is the answer:  import json from flaskproject.models import Post from flaskproject import db  with open('posts.json', 'r') as f: 	posts_dict = json.load(f) 	 for post in posts_dict:     post = Post(title=post['title'], content=post['content'], user_id=post['user_id'])     db.session.add(post)     db.session.commit()

author: @tatangasakarya8057
text: Json file upload simple solution as follows; content = json data for i in content:     post = Post(title=i["title"], content=i["content"], user_id= i["user_id"])           db.session.add(post)     db.session.commit()  You can do it on routes.py buy running the code just ONCE ! You should remove the code after the installation !

text: In case anyone wants to add the json file into the db, i just figure it out a way of doing it:  run python from flaskblog import db from flaskblog.models import Post import json  file = open('<path-to-your-file>'. 'r') data = json.load(file)  for x in data:      post = Post(title = x.get('title'), content = x.get('content'), user_id = x.get('user_id'))      db.session.add(post)  db.session.add(commit)

author: @ian_senior
text: if you want a script to import all of the posts from the json file, then follow the instructions below which will download the json file to the directory using the command line then you need to go into the python shell and create the posts (make sure you have 2 users already created first with user.id 's 1 and 2).  also, if you don't already have wget then you can get it with brew install wget otherwise, just download the json file anyway you want and put it in Flask_Blog directory and then skip the wget command and start with line 2 - python below...   on the command line inside the Flask_Blog root directory:   wget https://github.com/CoreyMSchafer/code_snippets/blob/master/Python/Flask_Blog/snippets/posts.json python import json from flaskblog import db from flaskblog.models import User, Post with open('posts.json', 'r') as read_file:     data = json.load(read_file) for record in data:     user = User.query.get(record['user_id']     post = Post()     post.title = record['title']     post.content = record['content']     post.author = user     db.session.add(post)     db.session.commit()

author: @enginerol
text: If anyone wanted to add next and previous page links to the pagination here is the code: {% if posts.has_prev %} « {% endif %} {% for page_num in posts.iter_pages(left_edge=1, right_edge=1, left_current=1, right_current=2) %} {% if page_num %} {% if posts.page == page_num %} {{ page_num }} {% else %} {{ page_num }} {% endif %} {% else %} ... {% endif %} {% if posts.has_next %} » {% endif %}

author: @1cannon3
text: ‚å®Ô∏è 1:30 Introduction to flask SQLAlchemy paginate method ‚å®Ô∏è 1:45 Changing our db query in our /home route from .all( ) to .paginate( )  ‚å®Ô∏è 2:00 Using the command line to investigate the .paginate( ) method  ‚å®Ô∏è 3:08 The ‚ÄúPagination‚Äù object and its attributes     ‚Äî 3:15 Using the dir( ) function, i.e. dir(post)         ‚Äî 3:32 Investigating the ‚Äúpage‚Äù object         ‚Äî 3:43 Investigating the ‚Äúper_page‚Äù attribute     ‚Äî 3:45 posts.per_page     ‚Äî 4:30 the last 5 blog posts are on second page because default is set to 20 items per page     ‚Äî 4:36 How to access second page of items     ‚Äî 4:50 posts = Post.query.paginate(page=2)     ‚Äî 5:14 changing the number of posts per page         ‚Äî 4:50 posts = Post.query.paginate(per_page=5) #five per page  ‚å®Ô∏è 6:30 returning to app/routes.py to integrate pagination     ‚Äî 6:55 Setting the post per page = 5     ‚Äî 6:55 Post.query.paginate(per_page=5)     ‚Äî 7:20 Grabbing the page we want a opposed to the default, page 1         ‚Äî ^ 6:55 We obtain this from a query parameter in the url, requests library     ‚Äî 6:55 Post.query.paginate(per_page=5)     ‚Äî 8:05 Updating home.html template to reflect changes     ‚Äî 8:52 Currently links to other pages are not wired up     ‚Äî 8:56 manually pass query parameter to test other pages     ‚Äî 9:08 ‚Ä¶?page=2      ‚å®Ô∏è 9:34 Update template to display links/buttons to next pages     ‚Äî 6:55 Setting the post per page = 5     ‚Äî 10:05 Using the command line to investigate how to do this     ‚Äî 10:54 Intro to the method .iter_pages( )         ‚Äî 11:22 How modern webpages display the page sequence to user         ‚Äî 11:50 Passing arguments to .iter_pages( ) to limit/modify amount of pages displayed to user         ‚Äî 12:10 Updating home.html template to display all page links via button         ‚Äî 16:44 Styling with bootstrap to show the current page the user is on      ‚å®Ô∏è 19:13 Sorting posts by date created     ‚Äî 19:44 This done by reordering in our query     ‚Äî 20:04 This will be achieved via routes.py     ‚Äî 20:10 VERY SIMPLE! just add .order_by(Post.date_posted.desc()) to the bd query         ‚Äî 20:36 Post.query.orer_by(Post.date_posted.desc()).paginate(page=page, per_page=5)  ‚å®Ô∏è 21:19 Lastly, creating route for when you click on a specific user     ‚Äî 21:42 Corey creates the new route     ‚Äî 22:08 The new route is /user/<str:username>     ‚Äî 22:48 Creating the db query within this new route (we need to filter by username now)     ‚Äî 24:39 Creating a new template for a specific users page (user_posts.html)     ‚Äî 27:30 We need to update the href for home.html and post.html     ‚Äî 28:05 Updating the pagination links on user_posts.html

author: @johnphoebus9664
text: [[SOLVED]] EDITED so for an in page link, like a modal, you can use # + string + {link name} So in basic html the href would be like #modal_1 in JNinja it would be "#modal{{ item.id}}" where you're looping over items and want to have a corresponding modal id link in the same page. Hope that helps if anyone has the same issue    Hey @coreyschafer, do you have any suggestions for docs/examples that would allow modal population? The issue I'm having is linking the modal id to the thumbnail (row of thumbnail images, modal popups with larger image plus text)

author: @slavoie
text: 23:48 ... Alternative to line continuation with backslashes ‚Üí Using parentheses instead of backslashes I prefer to wrap long lines with parentheses as I find it more readable with less symbols in the end (...depending on the number of wraps!). For this particular case, the Python code with backslashes is the following:  posts = Post.query.filter_by(author=user)\         .order_by(Post.date_posted.desc())\         .paginate(page=page, per_page=5)  Now, we can also use parentheses:  posts = (Post.query.filter_by(author=user)                   .order_by(Post.date_posted.desc())                   .paginate(page=page, per_page=5)          )  I like this way of doing it because you can visually indent everything at exactly the same horizontal position in your file. An added bonus here is that it becomes very easy to merge lines again without having to care about removing the backslashes. Anyway, I thought somebody could find that useful ‚ò∫.  Many thanks to Corey for this incredible series!!! It is fantastically well put!

author: @andrewparmar
text: To quickly add the posts Corey's is using (see link in description above) you can use the following in a python console opened from your project root directory. Just make sure you have one user created.  from flaskblog.models import Post from flaskblog import db  posts = <PASTE COREY'S JSON HERE>  for my_post in posts:     post_save = Post(title=my_post['title'], content=my_post['content'], user_id=1)     db.session.add(post)     db.session.commit()
